dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KIDS and FAMILY mill about in front of an elevated stage bedecked with rows of folding chairs. A giant banner reads: “SOUTHLAND DISTRICT’S 15TH ANNUAL REGIONAL SPELLING BEE.. NEXT STOP, WASHINGTON D.C.!1!!” At the snack table, GUY DUNCAN, disheveled 30s, shoves do into the worn pockets of his shitty blazer.

dialogues.speaker: CRISPLY DRESSED DAD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You must be so proud. I know I am. Guy looks up to see a CRISPLY DRESSED DAD. CRISPLY DRESSED DAD (CONT’D) Aren't kids amazing? Which one’s yours? Guy tears into a donut. An avalanche of powdered sugar fa down his blazer.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: (full mouth) Are you fucking kidding me? Guy shambles away, leaving the Dad confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PAUNCHY WOMAN in a SALMON COLORED PANTSUIT steps behind microphone and dartles a smile out into the gymnasium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OOOOKAY everyone! The Spelling Bee is about to begin so will all of our noble competitors please take their seats up on stage. Parents take their seats down below as the students make their way up on stage. Guy sits between two students up on the stage in the back row. He looks at the OVERWEIGHT BOY, 12, sitting on his left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ. Would it kill you to lose some weight? I barely have any room here. The overweight boy self-consciously looks away. In front, Salmon Pantsuit notices Guy sitting up on stage

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Sir? Guy morosely looks up. SALMON PANTSUIT (CONT’D) (precious tone) These seats are for the competitors, only, so if you can just-

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: I am a competitor. Salmon Pantsuit chuckles just for a moment. But Guy doesn

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy stands outside with Salmon Pantsuit and the TWO OTHER JUDGES- a SMALL, BALD MAN, 70s, with huge eye GLASSES and WOMAN, 50s, proudly wearing a BEDAZZLED DENIM VEST. Guys sucks on his teeth as all three scrutinize a shitty tattered PIECE OF PAPER. The Bald Judge puts his huge glasses on, making his eyes big as planets, which startles Guy.

dialogues.speaker: BALD GLASSES
dialogues.text: (old man forcefulness) Mr. Duncan, I’m not going to allow it. You are not eligible. In any fashion, way, shape, or manner! The Bald Judge pulls his huge glasses off.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: NO, your Honor, YOU'RE OUT OF

dialogues.speaker: ORDER
dialogues.text: (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Page thirty nine of the Scribbs National Spelling Bee rule book. Rule Twenty Four Sub point B. Quote: “The speller must not have passed beyond the eighth grade on or before February 1, 2011.” That, Sir, is a rule made by YOUR

dialogues.speaker: INSTITUTE, NOT MINE
dialogues.text: (re: shitty tattered paper) You’re looking at my transcript! Try not to wrinkle it any more than it is, okay? As you can see, I haven't passed beyond the eighth grade. Not on or before February 1, 2011! Not ever!

dialogues.speaker: BALD GLASSES
dialogues.text: That may be but-

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: -Page sixty nine of the Scribbs Institute National Spelling Bee rule book. Rule Fifty One Sub Point A: “The speller must not have earned a high school diploma or the legal equivalent of a high school diploma.” Guess what, chicken butts? I haven’t! A total of 83 paragraphs, five hundred and eighty one lines of rules in your rule book and I am complying with every stupid one of them!

dialogues.speaker: BEDAZZLED JUDGE
dialogues.text: The Spelling Bee is meant for kids. Not adults who couldn’t even graduate the 8th Grade.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: “Couldn't?” “Couldn't?” So now you’re saying you won’t let me participate because you think I’m stupid? Did you just call me fucking retarded?

dialogues.speaker: BEDAZZLED JUDGE
dialogues.text: (flustered) That’s not what I meant at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There’s no need for such salty language, Mr. Duncan! SALMON PANTSUIT (CONT’D) You don’t have a sponsor present. Every speller must be sponsored by a nationally published newspaper. JENNY WIDGEON, 30s, approaches.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Guy! There you are! (to Judges) Jenny Widgeon. Daily Probe- Guy’s sponsor. Sorry I’m late.

dialogues.speaker: BALD GLASSES
dialogues.text: The Daily Pro- HA! That’s not a newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Well let’s not argue over semantics, shall we?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: They don’t want to let me participate.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (feigning shock, gasps) They don’t want to let you participate?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: And they called me a retarded. Jenny pulls out her cellphone. Dials. Waits.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (into cellphone) You were right. Ok. Thanks. Jenny slams her cell off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that? Who did you just talk to?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Lead council of The Daily Probe’s legal team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They’re more like Piranhas with scorpion tails for dicks than actual lawyers.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: As you can guess, the Daily Probe is involved in its fare share of legal suits and boy do these guys know how to gum up the works! So, in about a half hour you will receive a Temporary Restraining Order and Preliminary Injunction prohibiting the continuation of this competition until we clear this whole legal matter up. Jenny cringes, whispers.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: BEDAZZLED JUDGE
dialogues.text: Legal matter? This isn’t a legal matter!

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: It is now. We're suing the three of you personally as well as The Scribbs Institute for discrimination and fraud for the amount of ten million dollars. All the color drains out of the Judges’ faces.

dialogues.speaker: BALD GLASSES
dialogues.text: How dare you try to hijack this spelling bee! You can’t do that!

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Hmm. Maybe. Maybe not. Again. Semantics. But getting down to the bottom of that will take weeks. Months.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Until then, no spelling bee. Hey, can I at least stay to watch you tell that entire gymnasium full of kids and parents that they won’t get their shot at the Nationals. Salmon Pantsuit nervously looks at the other judges.  She has no choice, it seems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (resigned) The rules are the rules, I guess. Salmon Pantsuit eyeballs Jenny’s phone. SALMON PANTSUIT (CONT’D) So can you just...

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Oh, right. Yes. Certainly. Jenny speed dials her cellphone.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yep. Yep. Yeeep. Okay. Jenny hangs up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, okay. Looks like we have a spelling bee to get to! Salmon Pantsuit looks like she swallowed a wasp. INT. GYMNASIUM, JUDGE’S TABLE A crowd of concerned parents has bloomed around the table

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There’s nothing we can do about the loophole he found. He’s clearly an alcoholic or a drug tweaker. I think the least unpleasant option is to just humor his derangement a bit, let him participate, and when he loses, his pathetic reality of a life will sink in. The best child will win. I assure you. Social justice will prevail. Don’t you all believe in your kids? I do! The parents nod. SALMON PANTSUIT (CONT’D) Then let’s be the bigger people in this situation, mkay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brace-Faced girl stands behind the microphone. Bald Glass is the proctor.

dialogues.speaker: BALD GLASSES
dialogues.text: Oleaginous.

dialogues.speaker: BRACES
dialogues.text: Oleaginous?

dialogues.speaker: BALD GLASSES
dialogues.text: Oleaginous.

dialogues.speaker: BRACES
dialogues.text: Oleaginous. Can I have the definition, please? Bald Glasses shoots Guy a look.

dialogues.speaker: BALD GLASSES
dialogues.text: “Having the nature or qualities of oil.” Or “Unctuous; fawning; smarmy.” Oleaginous. Guy subtly scratches his nose with his middle finger.

dialogues.speaker: BRACES
dialogues.text: Oleaginous. Can I have the language of origin?

dialogues.speaker: BALD GLASSES
dialogues.text: Latin.

dialogues.speaker: BRACES
dialogues.text: Oleaginous. Does it contain the Latin root “olea” meaning “olive?”

dialogues.speaker: BALD GLASSES
dialogues.text: That is correct.

dialogues.speaker: BRACES
dialogues.text: Oleaginous... Brace-Faced Girl starts ghost-spelling the word in her ha

dialogues.speaker: BRACES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oleaginous. Can you use it ina sentence?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Oh my God! All the kids sitting around Guy squirm with discomfort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “The oleaginous man knew he shouldn’t attend the party, but came anyway.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: (cough) Koughissmyass.

dialogues.speaker: BRACES
dialogues.text: Oleaginous. Brace-Faced Girl ghost-spells it in her hand again.

dialogues.speaker: BRACES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oleaginous.

dialogues.speaker: BALD GLASSES
dialogues.text: Oleaginous.

dialogues.speaker: BRACES
dialogues.text: Oleaginous. Can you tell me the part of speech?

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: Adjective. Guy turns to the Overweight Boy.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: No shit it’s an adjective. She ghost-spells it one more time.

dialogues.speaker: BRACES
dialogues.text: Oleaginous. Any other pronunciations?

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BRACES
dialogues.text: Oleaginous. O-L-E-A-G-I-N-O-U-S. Oleaginous.

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: That is correct. Everyone in the room applauds except Guy. Relieved, Brace Faced Girl sits back down. Next, a BOY, 11, with a HUGE MOLE on his cheek walks to t microphone. Guy leans over to the Overweight Boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: Mole) Hey, if he ever ends up in prison I know what his cell-wife will be aiming for every single time! Am I right? Am I right? The Overweight Boy nervously shifts in his seat.

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: Recidivism.

dialogues.speaker: MOLE
dialogues.text: Recidivism.

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: Recidivism.

dialogues.speaker: MOLE
dialogues.text: Recidivism.

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: Recidivism.

dialogues.speaker: MOLE
dialogues.text: Recidivism. Can I have the definition?

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: “AR tendency to lapse into a previous condition or pattern of behavior; especially, a falling back or relapse into prior criminal habits.” Recidivism.

dialogues.speaker: MOLE
dialogues.text: Recidivism. Can I have the part of speech?

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: Noun. Mole ghost spells it in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: MOLE
dialogues.text: Recidivism. Can you please use it in a sentence? Guy turns to the Brace-Faced Girl.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Holy balls, who doesn’t know this fucking word, huh? Jesus. You. Are. All. So. Lame.  10.

dialogues.speaker: MOLE
dialogues.text: R-E-C-E-D-I-V-I-S-M. Recidivism. Bedazzled Vest sadly hits a crude buzzer. The parents in audience “AWWWs” but applauds with appreciation for the attempt. Guy’s laughter erupts over it all. Mole lowers his head Charlie Brown style and walks off th stage. The applause dies down and everyone sits uncomfortably as Guy’s laughter continues to ring through the gymnasium. Back in the seats, Jenny shakes her head from Guy’s obnoxiousness. Finally, Guy finishes, dabs his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Oh, so pathetic. Hoo... Guy notices everyone’s waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: GUY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m up. Guy moves to the mic. The crowd murmurs. Bald Glasses sighs.

dialogues.speaker: BALD GLASSES
dialogues.text: Absquatulate-

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: (impatient. Quick.) A-B-S-Q-U-A-T-U-L-A-T-E. Guy turns and heads back to his seat.

dialogues.speaker: BALD GLASSES
dialogues.text: (Horrified. Surprised.) That’s- That’s correct. Nobody applauds. Just silent shock. Back at his seat, an evil smile creeps across Guy’s face he addresses the kids sitting around him.  11.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: I hope all of your pillow cases are waterproof, because tonight they’re gonna be soaked with lots of nerdy little snot tears! Boo hoo hoo...

dialogues.speaker: HIS ARM.
dialogues.text: An ANGRY MOB of parents burst out after him, throwing cof cups and donuts. Jenny screeches her car to a stop in Guy’s path.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (half reluctant)

dialogues.speaker: GET IN IF YOU WANT TO LIVE
dialogues.text: Guy quickly piles in and slams down the lock. A HOME BAKED MOM hawks an angry LOOGI on the window right level with Guy’s face. As the loogi drips down the window, the Crisply Dressed D rushes the car and screams:

dialogues.speaker: YOU ARE THE DEVIL
dialogues.text: The car peels out of the parking lot just as Crisply Dres Dad launches a fold-up chair, smashing a tail light.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Guy slouches in the seat next to his trophy. Jenny drives like a bat out of hell’s ass.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Did you see that back there?! Total Parentocalypse! You owe me a tail light!  12.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Just watch your driving, will you?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: “Grown man goes to National Spelling Bee!" by Jenny Widgeon. Oh, God. This is the only time I wished the nation’s illiteracy rate was even higher.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: I’m glad I could help.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Nonono. Thank you! Thank you for walking into the Probe and convincing my editors to help you pull off this craptastic stunt!

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: (mocking) Wah! I have integrity but the world won't let me show it. Wah!

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Hey! I ama real reporter, you get that? I’ve covered presidential elections! I’ve uncovered international corporate scandals! And if it wasn’t for the collapse of the newspaper business I’d still be doing that.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Here’s a headline for you: I DON’T GIVE A DANCING SHIT.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Packing for Washington D.C. is going to be simple for you, isn’t it? Because you just stuff all of your clothes in the hole where your heart would be if you had one. You’re your own carry on!

dialogues.speaker: SAME TIME
dialogues.text: Jenny’s car speeds away as we pan up to a PASSENGER PLANE FLYING OVERHEAD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy sits with his eyes shut tight. Jenny sits next to him She lowers Guy’s tray and places a tape recorder on it in front of him. Guy opens his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: -..the fuck’s this?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Time for a obligatory interview.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Not now. I’m getting my beauty rest.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Yeah, and it’s really working for you. It is. I mean it. Alright. Where to begin? Hmm. I wonder. Oh yeah! Why are you doing this? Why have you decided, at this late stage in your life, to compete against children in the National Spelling Bee?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Sleepy time. Guy points to his closed eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: You gonna make this hard or easy? Guy flips her the bird.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve had bigger challenges than you. Trust me. Guy remains still, his eyes shut. Jenny impatiently snaps her recorder up.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fine. I’m going to the bathroom. We'll settle this later. Jenny gets out of her seat and storms up the aisle. Guy keeps his eyes closed. Suddenly, an INDIAN BOY, 12, CHAITANYA CHOPRA- as awkward as the day is long- pops up the seat behind Jenny's.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: Hi. I’m Chaitanya Chopra.  14.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: (annoyed) What?

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: My name.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Congratufuckinlations.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: What’s your name? Guy says nothing. Chaitanya Chaitanya CHAITANYA (CONT’D) What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Guy. stares at Guy squeezing his eyes shut.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: “Guy” what?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Does it matter?

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: I’m going to the National Spelling Bee. My parents are up in first class. My Dad says that economy class builds character.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: (who cares) Amazing. leans over Guy a bit more, looks out of his window.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: You have a great view. I’ve gone to the National Spelling Bee twice before. I overheard you say you're going to the National Spelling Bee, too. You’re the grown-up who’s competing, huh? Guy keeps his eyes shut. Says nothing. CHAITANYA (CONT’D) I heard about you. What was your winning word?  15. Nothing from Guy. CHAITANYA (CONT’D) Your word? Your winning word?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: (annoyed) What?

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: What was the word you spelled to win your regional? To get here? Mine was “Intelligentsia.”

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: I don’t fucking remember.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: Come on, try to remember.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Shit, I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: Think. You should remember. How can you forget? It’s sucha special word.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: (tired) “Autofellatio.”

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: I’ve never heard of that word. What’s it’s origin?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Loneliness.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: No that can’t be right...I know "BRuto” is of Greek origin meaning “self,” right? Fellatio...fellatio fellatio... is that derived from the Latin “fellare” meaning to suck?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: (incredibly annoyed) Listen, don’t get your tits ina tangle. It’s just a fucking word. Jesus!  16. Guy closes his eyes again.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: Hey, can I trade seats with you? I enjoy sitting next to the window on airplanes.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: (flustered) Because my seat is over an especially important part of the plane. I move and the plane won’t be balanced and we'll all plummet and crash in a fiery nightmarish death.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: (unbelieving) What? Are you sure? Across the aisle, A LITTLE BOY, 7, overhears this. He loo straight ahead and sits rigid, completely freaked out.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Shit. See what you did? Now I got to take an eight-ball piss. Guy gets up.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: wooo! I DON’T WANT TO DIE!!! Guy walks up the aisle to the lavatory as FLIGHT ATTENDAN rush past him to the screaming boy.

dialogues.speaker: ESPN INTRO
dialogues.text: Sweeping music rises as A Camera pans across an empty mid-western school auditori A COLLAGE of children’s voices start spelling random lett but all at once.

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR
dialogues.text: Can you hear the buzz of the bee?  17. Various shots of spellers in moments of victory and defea NARRATOR (CONT’D) The buzz that started long ago. We all have our memories of when we first heard it. Various shots of chairs with numbers. Of dictionary pages flipping. NARRATOR (CONT’D) An old school-time competition is about to capture your imagination. The music starts to swell. NARRATOR (CONT’D) We all have our hometown heroes. But the genius of these competitors is spellbinding. Images of victorious kids pop up one after another. NARRATOR (CONT’D) And like bees to honey, our lust for competition leads us hungrily to the epicenter of this quest for greatness. Images of one teen after another taking the giant check f SCRIBBS COO BILL BOWMAN, 60s- executively handsome for hi age. NARRATOR (CONT’D) The prize is just a word away, and those who compete want to take that check from the Legendary Scribbs coo Bill Bowman. They've dreamed of it all their lives. Images of teens holding up the spelling bee trophy... NARRATOR (CONT’D) And that's why it's the drama of “The Bee." So, can you hear the buzz? Well, can you? The images suddenly turn to MONDAY NIGHT FOOTBALL type graphics as the faint sound of bee buzzing morphs into th robotic WHUP WHUP WHUP of military helicopters as...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly TWO YUCKITY YUCK ANNOUNCERS appear in the ballro auditorium in front of the stage.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Welcome everyone to the 85th annual Scribbs Institute National Spelling Bee, I’m Chuck Wilde coming at you live from the Historic State Plaza Hotel here in the heart of our country’s only capital, Washington

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: And I’m Peter Yates. Chuck, over the years the popularity of the National Spelling Bee has grown to sick proportions and this year viewership promises to rival that of any championship sporting event.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: You don’t have to spell that out for me, Pete. What can we say? The world loves a good showdown and what. A. Showdown. It will be! Let’s get to know some of this year’s most noteworthy alphabet gladiators! From here on out, all broadcast graphics of names will be produced by these violent mechanical bees blowing things and shooting lasers with their stingers. Thunderous music plays over montages of pre-filmed, in-st shots of competitors standing awkwardly for the camera. The insane graphics and production go totally against the grain of how nerdy they all actually are... JOYCE SACKS, 14 years-old with pigtails, acne and a crook grin.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Joyce Sacks. A fourteen year old spelling assassin hailing from Plymouth Minnesota. Came in 8th last year but this year retreat is not an option. Word has it that she’s been working with three different coaches- one for English, one for Greek and one for Latin- and she’s ready to declare “All your bases are belong to us!”  19. Next, BAXTER FLOURNEY, 9, BRACES and a BOWL HAIRCUT complimented by uncomfortable glances at the camera.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: That kid with braces stealing your soul with his death stare? Oh nothing, just nine year-old mind killer Baxter Flourney from Worcester, Massachusetts. His Dad crushed the National Spelling Bee in 1980 at the age of 9. Last year, his older brother Benjamin beheaded first place at the age of 9. And what does this mean? The Bee runs thick in his blood and he’s about spill some of his competition’s! Next, Chaitanya, the boy from the airplane...

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Some say that twelve year-old Chaitanya Chopra from Olathe, Kansas has ice for blood. Others say that if you opened up his skull you’d find Stephen Hawking AND Albert Einstein in a mixed martial arts fight. Whatever the truth is, Chaitanya has placed third for the last two years and he isn’t going to take it anymore! He’s focused. He wants it. And word on the street is he’s gonna spine-rip anyone who gets in his way! The graphics explode to reveal ERIC TAI, 14- weird is an understatement.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Don’t let his virgin exterior fool you! Eric Tai from San Diego California is an absolute spelling bee Mongoose! Two years ago, he placed second. Last year, he lost by a syllable to Benjamin Flourney. One syllable! Now, Eric wants to proverbially pop out of the Mekong Delta with a knife in his mouth and disembowel the final round. Next we see a montage of rough video footage of Guy constantly walking away from the camera and flipping the bird.  20.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And finally, in what has been the strangest turn of events in Bee history, we have contestant Guy Duncan from St. Louis, Missouri. Oh, did we forget to mention? Guy's thirty four years-old! This man has made huge waves in the competitive spelling world by exposing and capitalizing on a loophole in the competition’s rules, and OH MAMA! Have things been topsy-turvy! But he’s here and the only way we’re gonna get rid of him is if he loses! Finally, we see quick footage cuts of Scribbs COO Bill Bo all around the world: Spoon feeding a hungry African chil skydiving, Ostrich racing, climbing to the top of a human tower in Sardinia.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And all of this spelling bee action is constantly promoted, lauded, and endorsed by one of America’s most charismatic COOs, Scribbs Institute’s own Bill Bowman. We cut to a LIVE SATELLITE FEED of Bowman, donning an X-G helmet, being harnessed to a zipline that stretches beyon the fiery lip of a volcano!

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We have Mr. Bowman joining us on a live feed right now to share a few words.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Thanks Chuck, Pete. I’m sorry I’m not in town yet. I’m at the mouth of the Kilauea Volcano on the island of Kauai, as I zipline across all the major volcanos of the world in my ongoing attempt to raise awareness about the literacy epidemic in America. You know, it’s a lot more dangerous than it looks- and I’m talking about our literacy rate, not the ziplining. But never fear, I’1l make it to Washington in time to hand out first prize to our next National Spelling Bee champion. Who will be the next champion? I don’t know. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I’1l tell you this, you can’t be a Bee champion, unless you've shown honor, sportsmanship and integrity. It’s just impossible. As always, I can’t wait to meet all of our noble competitors. Well, most of them. I/‘11 be arriving with high hopes, as well as that much loved giant check! Bowman turns away from the camera, gives the people aroun him a thumbs-up, and ZIPLINES OVER THE VOLCANO!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy and Jenny follow a crisply walking REGISTRATION REP d the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy and Jenny enter the office to find NATIONAL SPELLING DIRECTOR BERNICE DEAGAN, 40s, tall, peter pan hair, sitti behind the hotel manager's desk. Director Deagan motions toward the two seats before the d

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR DEAGAN
dialogues.text: Have a seat. I’m Bernice Deagan, Director of the National Spelling Bee. (beat) Struthious.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR DEAGAN
dialogues.text: S-T-R-U-T-H-I-0-U-S. Struthious. That was my winning word. 1973. National Champion. Just thought you should know that. If you didn’t already.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR DEAGAN
dialogues.text: Guy. I don’t like you.  22.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Listen-

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR DEAGAN
dialogues.text: Now you just shoosh! (beat) You know, when I was a little girl, I was always picked last in P.E. I hated sports. That’s probably what, thankfully, thrust me into the welcoming bosom of the spelling bee. Now, I’m proud to say, we are projected to have more viewers than the Superbowl. That feels kinda nice to say out loud. So how did I accomplish this? Elbow grease? Yes. Hard work? Maybe. Integrity? You betcha. But what I didn’t do is use slimy gimmicks just as yourself! Director Deagan pulls out a competitor number from her de DIRECTOR DEAGAN (CONT’D) So I wanted to personally give you your number... She moves around the table and hangs it around Guy’s neck

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR DEAGAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You think you’re smart because you found a loophole- and you're taking advantage of it. B-R-A-V-O. But I know you’re not smarter than even the poorest speller in this competition. So may this number serve as the noose you hang yourself by.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Wow. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR DEAGAN
dialogues.text: Don’t mention it. Oh, and one other thing. I personally arranged your hotel accommodations for you. Just wanted you to know that.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: You shouldn't have.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR DEAGAN
dialogues.text: But I did.  23.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: So that all you got? Some sort of weird veiled threat? You could have done that in an e- mail. Jesus. Guy gets up. Jenny follows.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR DEAGAN
dialogues.text: I just thought it would mean more in person.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Not in this day and age! Guy exits.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR DEAGAN
dialogues.text: (calling after him) I’m watching you.

dialogues.speaker: GUY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (calling back)

dialogues.speaker: GOOD
dialogues.text: The door slams behind Guy and Jenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is packed with Bee parents and kids. Guy bulldo his way through. Jenny keeps up.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Hey! Where are you going? The contestant ice cream social is that way! Guy walks off, raising his middle finger as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to herself) Wow. What a complete asshole. INT. ELEVATOR —- MOMENTS LATER As the doors start to close, Guy sees Chaitanya running toward the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: Hold the door!  24. Guy doesn’t budge, forcing Chaitanya to wrestle between t doors himself. CHAITANYA (CONT’D) Whew! I made it. Hey, I know you! Guy doesn’t answer. CHAITANYA (CONT’D) You’re Guy, from the airplane. Guy stays silent.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: No I’m not.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: I’m Chaitanya, remember? Cool. I like words. What’s your favorite word? Guy tries to ignore him. CHAITANYA (CONT’D) Come on. What’s your favorite word in the whole wide world?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: I don’t-

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: -Favorite word?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: I don’t have a favorite word.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: Mine is “assassin.” It just sounds so cool, you know? Assassin. Assassin. Assassin. Assassin. ASSasSIN. AssASSin. Guy presses the button some more. CHAITANYA (CONT’D) What’s yours?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: (shut up) I. Don’t. Have. One.  25.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: Of course you do. Everyone does. I bet you even Helen Keller had a favorite word. She was blind and deaf. Everyone’s got a favorite word.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Well, I guess I’m a fucking oddball, then.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: I bet Abraham Lincoln had a favorite word. Mark Twain. Neil Armstrong. Charles Schultz. Bill Clinton. Charlie Chaplin...and he did silent films.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: NO SHIT! BUT I DON’T!

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: Well, if you were to have one what would it be?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: (gritted teeth) I don’t.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: Say you're on a desert island and this Gorilla comes out of the jungle and holds a gun to your head and says, “HOO HOO! Tell me what your favorite word is!” What would you say? Guy gets flustered.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Listen, Chet...Chick...whatever the fuck your name is.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: Chaitanya.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: Okay. The elevator door opens and Guy angrily pours out.  26.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Guy can open the door all the way, it hits the mattress, which is ON THE FLOOR.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: What the... Guy fights his way in to see that the gray, tiny room is nothing but a mattress flanked by gray industrial shelves On the other wall stands a deep, mildewed washbasin... AND _NO BATHROOM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy takes a close look at the door. He notices the faded indentation of the words “Cleaning Staff Only” underneath polished brass room number. Guy clenches his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guys stands before a BARBIE DOLL FRONT DESK CLERK, 20s.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DESK REPRESENTATIVE
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, the hotel is completely sold out.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: I don’t have a bathroom!

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DESK
dialogues.text: (patronizing) Yeah. Ouch.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: I_DON’T HAVE A BATHROOM. The front desk clerk crinkles her nose. Guy storms away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small, stylish bar.  Guy stands out like a black-nailed thumb amongst this polished, smiling crowd. 27. He spots Jenny sitting at the bar. The only open seat is right next to her.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Bartender. Old Fashioned. If Guy wants booze, he has no choice. He sighs and sits d next to her.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Bartender) Make that two. (to Guy) No mini-bar, huh?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: No nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I think the Queen Bee is sending you a message.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Damn Skippy.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Man. There are so many parents around here. This place is bursting in the seems with them.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: No shit.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Where are your parents?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Oh Jesus Christ. I just want to have a drink in peace. Is that too much to ask?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Listen, I’m trying to make the best out of my situation, okay? I’m supposed to cover you, so I’m going to do it the best way I know how. By asking questions. By starting with the basics. By getting to know you.  28.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Well do me a favor and don’t get to know me. Just report what you see, and leave it at that. Stop trying so hard.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: You're like an insolent child hiding secrets from his mother.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Heh, you don’t amount to half the broad my mother was! Guy realizes he just revealed a personal fact. He grimace and curses at himself under his breath. Slugs his drink.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. When did she die?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Fuck off. Jenny flags the bartender.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I’m gonna need another.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: I’m gonna need two!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now several empty glasses sit before Guy and Jenny...

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Look, it’s my job! I’m just doing my job.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Is that how you justify being what you are?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: What I am? Look at you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now twice as many empty glasses litter the bar in front o them. They both stubbornly sit, tipsy and angry.  29.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Look, screw you.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Whatever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With his pants around his ankles, Guy desperately humps J on his mattress.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Yes. YES! Don’t look at me. DON’T LOOK AT ME! DON’T LOOK AT ME. Guys cranes his head away to the side as far as he can- h face practically presses against the nasty mop sink.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ okay I’m not looking at you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy lies on the mattress on the floor as Jenny hurriedly her skirt back on.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Wow. That was a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: It was great for me, too.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I‘ll...I’11 see you tomorrow. Jenny leaves. Guy spots Jenny’s forgotten underwear on the floor. He pi them up. Shoves them in his pocket.  30. There’s a KNOCK on the door. Guy gets up. Opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Yeah, if you're so together then why'd you forget your under- Chaitanya standing there, holding a JAR OF NUTS.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: Sorry to bother you, but I heard you were still awake. Would you mind helping me open this jar of mixed nuts? Chaitanya peers past Guy. CHAITANYA (CONT’D) Wow. Small room. Guy slams the door in the boy's face. Chaitanya knocks some more. CHAITANYA (0.C.) (CONT’D) Can you help me? TI haven’t had anything to eat all night. I was studying my words so hard I missed room service hours and this jar is too hard for me to open. Guy opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Oh yeah well we all need something, don’t we? Life is filled with disappointment! Guy grabs the jar and SMASHES IT against the opposite wal He slams the door shut. Guy listens to see if Chaitanya has left.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: I...I was wondering if you wanted to be my friend. Guy opens the door.  31.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Listen Slum Dog, I dunno what makes you think that I want to be your friend but you better baba ghanoush that idea right out of your head! Guy slams the door.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Okay. It’s cool. I just thought it would be fun to study together before tomorrow. Drink soda pop from the mini-bar and stuff. Guy opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Your room has a mini-bar?

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: What about your Mom...Dad?

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: My Dad believes that I should learn how to be my own man, and that means staying in my own hotel room myself this weekend.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: What...is he in the room next door?

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: He’s staying at a fancier hotel a few blocks away.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: (hell yeah) Bummer.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: It's kind of neat. I get to jump on the bed as much as I want. But tonight I messed up and missed room service.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. CHAITANYA'’S HOTEL ROOM —- MOMENTS LATER Chaitanya happily picks through the mixed nuts AND BROKEN GLASS- now gathered in a wad of toilette paper- on the ho room desk. Guy leans into the mini-bar and pulls out every bottle of booze there is.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: (more focused on his drink) Careful of the fucking glass.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: Okay. I will. Chaitanya happily eats a nut. CHAITANYA (CONT’D) I think I know what your favorite word is.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Really.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: The “F” word. Guy ponders this. Shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: You say it a lot.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Everyone should.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: My father says bad words. But I’m not allowed to. What about your dad?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: I never knew my dad. But my mom said bad words a lot. You can say bad words. I don’t give a shit.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: I shouldn't.  33.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Do it. Who has the right to decide what is a bad word and what is a good word? Shouldn’t it be that whatever word best expresses how you feel is a good word? Do it. The very thought makes Chaitanya grin. Chaitanya Chaitanya

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Stop acting like a little fucking Quaker and do it.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: Okay. (relishing every syllable) Mutherfucker. laughs.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Did your soul burst into flames?

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: Okay. All done.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: You’re a real fucking weirdo, you know that? shrugs. Guy pours a mini rum into his glass.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: Do you like rum?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: You can be like a pirate with your rum! And if you had a cigarette you could be a total butt pirate!

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Don’t ever call me a butt pirate.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: Why? You smoke, don’t you?  34.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: “Butt Pirate” has nothing to do with cigarettes. Chaitanya blankly looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: GUY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You'll find out one day, I’m sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy sits asleep in the desk chair with his head lolled ba and a rope of drool stretching from his mouth. Chaitanya taps him on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: Hey. Hey! Guy starts awake. Chaitanya’s now in a pair of TRANSFORME PAJAMAS. Guy looks him up and down.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: The fuck happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: It’s morning. You passed out last night and I was scared to wake you. My Dad will be here any minute, you should go.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Fine. Fuck. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy shuffles down the hallway. He passes an INDIAN MAN go the other way.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Solemn a lick ‘em. Guy keeps his head low and walks on. The Indian Man turns and looks after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy and Jenny speed-walk down the hall. Guy stumbles alon completely hung-over.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Did I leave my underwear in your apartment last night?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Who knows?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: You look like hell.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: I don’t have a shower. An awkward beat.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Baxter Flourney’s in your round. He comes from Bee royalty.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: I’m so scared.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Maybe you should be. He’s awesome.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Right. Guy walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stage lights instantly hit Guy as he enters. Everyone murmurs as he makes his way to the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck and Pete are on the air.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Pure drama, Chuck. Pure drama. Ladies and Gentleman of the world, we have all one hundred and fifty competitors, let the Bee begin!  36. Guy passes Director Deagan, who grimaces to herself in disappointment that he made it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FAMILY gathers on the couch to watch the Spelling Bee..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crowds of SHOPPERS cluster around the FLATSCREEN DISPLAY, which is turned to the Bee...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BAR REGULARS order rounds of beer and shush each other as they watch the Bee...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOLDIERS huddle in a camouflage tent around a small TV th is tuned to the Bee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy finds his seat up on the stage right next to Baxter Flourney. A few rows up sits Chaitanya, who tries to get Guy’s attention to wave at him, but fails. The PROCTOR and JUDGES sit facing them, and a crowd of un parents watch from their seats. Jenny sits in the last se in the last row.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: First up, Ling Quan, 13 years old from Pleasanton, Oregon.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Chuck, Ling says when she grows up she wants to be president of the United States.  37.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: (chuckling) Not a chance. Pete shoots chuck a look.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...that...there is a single person who wouldn't vote for her. Let’s go to the competition. They both chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ASIAN GIRL LING, 13, BRACES, moves up to the microphon

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: Dactylogram.

dialogues.speaker: LING
dialogues.text: Dactylogram?

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: Dactylogram.

dialogues.speaker: LING
dialogues.text: Dactylogram.

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: Dactylogram. Guy rubs his temples.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Oh God. The Asian Girl ghost-spells in the palm of her hand.

dialogues.speaker: LING
dialogues.text: Can I have the definition, please?

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: A fingerprint.

dialogues.speaker: LING
dialogues.text: Dactylogram. Can I have the origin, please?  38.

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: Dactylogram. From a Greek combination dactylos meaning “fingers, toes.”

dialogues.speaker: LING
dialogues.text: Dactylogram.

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: Dactylogram. Ling ghost-spells in her palm one more time.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: I’m in hell. Guy turns to Baxter.

dialogues.speaker: GUY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey. Wassup. I’m Guy. You’re Baxter, right? Baxter snobbishly looks over at Guy.

dialogues.speaker: BAXTER
dialogues.text: I’m not supposed to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: BAXTER
dialogues.text: Because my Dad says you’re probably just some unemployed bum trying to steal the prize money that I deserve. And that you’re a cheater.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: BAXTER
dialogues.text: Yeah. Guy chuckles at this slight. Baxter inches away. Guy puts his hands in his pocket and discovers he still h Jenny’s underwear. Guy leans over to Baxter and nods out toward the audience.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Well, your Dad’s kind of right. I don’t blame him for being so angry. Do me a favor, will you?  39. Guy pulls JENNY’S UNDERWEAR out from his pocket. Wads it into Baxter’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: GUY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can you give these back to your mom? She left them in my room last night. I'd do it myself but your Dad’s around and who wants to deal with that. Good luck with the divorce, by the way. Divorces suck. Baxter’s snobbish look melts into shock.

dialogues.speaker: BAXTER
dialogues.text: What? Stunned, confused, Baxter takes the underwear, takes the news. The audience applauds as LING victoriously takes he seat.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Oh shit, you’re up. Not knowing what else to do, Baxter quickly shoves the underwear into his pocket. Blinking hard, Baxter walks up the mic- the underwear bulging in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Next up, probably the next Spelling Bee king, Baxter Flourney.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Pete, Baxter says he wants to be president of the United States when he grows up. And win a Nobel.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Well, shall we cast our votes now?

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: Noctivagant. Baxter looks out to his parents. His FATHER watches stern while his MOTHER offers a hopeful thumbs-up.  40. PROCTOR (CONT’D) Noctivagant. Baxter blinks back to consciousness.

dialogues.speaker: BAXTER
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, can you say the word again?

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: Noctivagant.

dialogues.speaker: BAXTER
dialogues.text: Noct...

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: Noctivagant. Baxter looks out at his parents again.

dialogues.speaker: BAXTER
dialogues.text: Noctivagant....definition?

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: “Going about in the night; night- wandering.”

dialogues.speaker: BAXTER
dialogues.text: Uh...Noctivagant. Can...can you use it in a sentence?

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: “The noctivagant alley cat kept the entire neighborhood up all night by sitting on the fence, yowling out to her many suitors.” The audience chuckles off this playful sentence. Is Baxte mother chuckling the most? Baxter tries hard to focus. He starts to ghost-spell in h hand, but he can’t concentrate. He sweats. He breathes hard.

dialogues.speaker: BAXTER
dialogues.text: Noctivagant. Other pron... pronunciations?

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: I have just Noctivagant. Baxter swallows hard.  4l.

dialogues.speaker: BAXTER
dialogues.text: Noctivagant. N-O-C-T-I-V-I-G-A-N- T. Noctivagant. A delicate DESK BELL tings to alert everyone that Baxter spelled the word incorrectly! The crowd “AWWs” in disappointment. Some gasp. Baxter’s parents erupt with surprise. Crushed, Baxter walks off th stage and down the isle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MOTHER on the couch gasps and covers her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A smile creeps across Guy’s face. Then he starts to laugh

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Well Chuck, not everybody is displeased by this shocker... The camera zooms in on Guy’s devilish grin.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Well, Chuck. Now that the room seems to have recovered from that shock, up next, something even weirder...Guy Duncan.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Guy said when he grows up he wants to be a...well, he’s already grown up.  42.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Most people believe that Guy is pulling a stunt, and he’ll immediately strike out here, let’s listen in and see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy heads to the mic.

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: Frabjous-—

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: (quick) F-R-A-B-J-O-U-S. Guy turns around and sits back down. He turns to all the kids around him.

dialogues.speaker: GUY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (ominous ) Are you ready to get your shit pushed in? The kids all look at Guy in shock.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: We pop around to televisions around the world as Guy easi spells his words throughout round one: On a television in a Barber shop...

dialogues.speaker: GUY, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: Fuck the ice cream, I want to grow up right now!  63. They both leave the alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sleepy DESK CLERK watches as Guy and Chaitanya drag t exhausted bodies across the lobby to the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Guy and Chaitanya both lean against the back of the eleva

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chaitanya stops at his door. Guy keeps shuffling on.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: Hey, Guy? This was like, the best night of my life. Are we friends now? Without turning around, Guy flips Chaitanya the bird, and steels a small smile to himself, but keeps on walking to room. CHAITANYA (CONT’D) Cool. Chaitanya, opens his door, where we see his father, the Indian man from before, sternly waiting for him inside. H goes in and the door closes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny and Guy walk down the hall to the next round. Guy keeps looking at Jenny, but whenever she looks at him, he looks away.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Fuck it. Yes, it was just me and my mom growing up. Life sucked, and then she died last year. It’s as simple as that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you like me.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: What? Don’t flatter yourself. You just suck at your job and I’m tired of watching you beg. Chaitanya approaches them.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: Guy! I wanted to give you something before the round starts. For good luck. 64. Chaitanya hands Guy his toy taxi that has been crudely converted with black and red markers, into a police car. This is the first time we see Guy being touched by anythi

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: I’m going to totally bust your nut.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: No, you don’t mean that.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: I do!

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: The nut busting...It’s not what you mean...I’m not...just say you’re going to kick my ass.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: Okay. See you in there!

dialogues.speaker: JENNA
dialogues.text: What was that all about? Guy puts the toy car in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Let’s go spell some fucking words.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: And welcome everyone who’s tuned in to watch Round Two of the Scribbs Institute National Spelling Bee. I wonder what today will offer, Pete?

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Ninety Nine problems, but I’m sure a misspelled bitch ain’t one of them, Chuck.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. HOTEL AUDITORIUM PROCTOR’S TABLE - SAME TIME Director Deagan leans over to the Proctor.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR DEAGAN
dialogues.text: Sorry. There was an error with the randomization programming, I need to give you the fix before the round.

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: Okay. Director Deagan inserts a USB stick into the Proctor’s computer and uploads the program, with a devilish smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy sits among the competitors, in his own personal hell, Round two drones on. A KOREAN BOY with Cowlick Hair stand in front of the mic.

dialogues.speaker: COWLICK
dialogues.text: Rhapsodize... can I please have the definition?

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: “To talk with extravagant enthusiasm.” Rhapsodize.

dialogues.speaker: COWLICK
dialogues.text: Rhapsodize. Any other pronunciations? Guy sees Joyce Sacks sitting in front of him. He taps her the shoulder.  66.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Joyce turns.

dialogues.speaker: GUY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's your Dad out there in the audience, right?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Guy pulls a pair of HIS OWN UNDERWEAR out of his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: This is kind of embarrassing, but he left these in my room last night and I don’t want to humiliate him by handing them back myself. It was just horseplay, I swear. (beat) He truly loves your mom. With horror, Joyce takes the underwear and stares at it f long beat. Tears well up in her eyes. Her lower lip quivers. Joyce stands up out of her seat. All eyes are directed at her as she points out into the audience at her father.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: (shrill)

dialogues.speaker: I KNEW IT
dialogues.text: Joyce storms off the stage. Guy smiles, pleasantly surprised. All the other kids remain seated, somewhat rattled. Joyce’s parents get up and run after her.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Annnnd end scene! Unbelievable! Joyce Sacks flames out without misspelling a single word!

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Pete, she caved like a skull hit with a ball peen hammer, Pete.  67.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I'd hate to have a look in your freezer.

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: I, um, apologize for that.

dialogues.speaker: COWLICK
dialogues.text: It’s okay. R-H-A-P-S-O-D-I-Z-E. Rhapsodize.

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: That is correct. The audience applauds.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: AND LEE PARK HITS A BULL’S-EYE!

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: Maybe one day Lee Park will have a park named after him. The “Lee Park Park.” And then they can add a park and ride adjacent to it. The “Lee Park Park Park and Ride.” Something to be proud of, Chuck.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Yeeesss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Guy’s turn. He turns to the kids as he gets up.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: I hope you’re fuckin’ ready, because I’m about to get all Optimus Prime on your asses. Guy steps up to the mic. He watches as the Proctor’s eyes WIDE for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: VOLCANOCONIOSIS.
dialogues.text: The audience gasps. Guy pauses.  68.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Can you spell Uh-oh, Chuck?

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Chances are I can spell it better than that word!

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Damn it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Director Deagan smiles. Leans forward in her chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy steps away from the mic for a moment. Paces. We think he’s panicking. But then he spots something in the back o the auditorium.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Thank God. I was worried there for a second. Guy waves to the back of the auditorium. Everyone turns around to find a wide-eyed WAITER from the hotel bar, hol a MARTINI.

dialogues.speaker: GUY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah, that’s me... Unsure, the waiter walks up the aisle to the stage.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: UN. BELIEVABLE! Guy is pulling a Thurston Howell the Third right here at the Bee! Director Deagan makes a B line to the Judges’ table.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Looks like Director Deagan doesn’t agree with Guy’s methodology.  69.

dialogues.speaker: PETE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: But I can tell you right now, Chuck, that Deagan’s gonna come up dryer than Grandma's sex toy on this one. There is no rule that states a contestant can’t drink during a round- because usually the contestants are under the legal age to drink.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who’s Afraid of Virginia Wolfe? Not this fella! After quietly conferring with the Judges, Director Deagan throws her arms up in the air and storms back to her seat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy watches Director Deagan go and then bends down to the waiter, takes the Martini.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: What’s the damage?

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Eleven dollars.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: ELEV- there better be like, angel semen in this drink, or something. The audience gasps as everything Guy’s saying is being pi up by the mic. Guy plops his room cardkey in the waiter’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: GUY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here, put it on the room account, and check back every once in awhile. I’m gonna dry out real fast.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Yessir. Guy leans into the mic.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. Sorry. (fast) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: C-A-N-OC-O-N-I-0-S-I-S.
dialogues.text: Guy unceremoniously returns to his seat with his drink.

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: (unbelieving) Correct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Director Deagan crosses her arms with a huff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We cut between Guy and the other competitors standing at mic. Guy spells lightning fast every time, and simply tur back to his seat, cocktail in hand, knowing he spelled correctly. The others pause, ghost-spell in their hands, spell with uncertainty. Angry viewers around the world boo and throw stuff at the TVs every time Guy is up...

dialogues.speaker: O-L-E-C-Y-S-TE-N-T-E-R-OS-T-O-M-I-E-
dialogues.text: Ss.

dialogues.speaker: FRECKLE FACED BOY
dialogues.text: Can I have the root origin please?

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: Pertinacious. Can that be used in a sentence please? As Chaitanya spells we see Guy very subtly spelling along with him...almost with encouraging enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: This is amazing! The luck of the draw is not going Guy’s way as it seems he’s getting every mile-long word in the English language!!!

dialogues.speaker: CAMBODIAN GIRL
dialogues.text: Hagridden. H-A-G-R-I-T-T-O-N. Ting! The girl’s face falls.

dialogues.speaker: -.-H-I-P.
dialogues.text: Ting! He's out. His lowers his head. Ting! Another girl is out. She turns to walk off as her face sours into a big sob. Ting! Another boy is out. He smacks his forehead and walk away. Ting! And another. He turns and leaves. Ting! And another. He turns and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: (burp spells)

dialogues.speaker: PROCTOR
dialogues.text: (horrified disappointed) That is correct. One clap can be heard in the back. Coming from Chaitanya. Guy spells one word after another...with more physical fl each time. By his last word, Guy’s busting ELVIS KARATE KICKS on his back to his seat. END MONTAGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pack of angry parents surround Director Deagan as she fights her way through.

dialogues.speaker: ANGRY MOM
dialogues.text: He’s in the final round! Director Deagan looks to all the angry parents.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR DEAGAN
dialogues.text: Okay, well, obviously I’m not going to resign. That would leave the Bee rudderless in this storm!

dialogues.speaker: BULLSHIT
dialogues.text: The crowd of parents grow loud with protest. Director Deagan, for the first time, looks like the pressure is getting to her. Elsewhere, Guy exits the ballroom amid very harsh stares. Chaitanya catches up with Guy.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: Alright! We're both in! Top twenty five! Chaitanya tries to hi-five Guy but misses and hits his ch Jenny approaches. CHAITANYA (CONT’D) I’m going to kick your ass. You want to eat dinner together? And then maybe study or something?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Yeah. I don’t know, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: Meet me in the lobby in like, an hour.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Yeah, alright. Chaitanya saunters off.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Did I just see what I just saw?  73.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: You have a friend?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Look. he’s an incredibly annoying kid and the only way to keep him from driving me insane is to deal with him.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Do you have a little buddy?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Hey! It’s none of your business, okay?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Okay! I was just joking. Have all the friends you want!

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: I will! I gotta go study. Guy storms away. Jenny calls after him.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I know you’re not studying you don’t study! Have fun with your buddy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy walks past the gift shop. Pauses. Turns to go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy stands in front of the magazine stand. Contemplating. With a smile, Guy grabs a Playboy Magazine. Guy passes the freezer. Then returns to quickly grab a pi of ice cream. Guy plops them both down at the register. The OLD LADY CLERK, 80s, raises her eyebrows.  74.

dialogues.speaker: OLD LADY CLERK
dialogues.text: Gettin’ ready for a wild night, huh? Guy slaps down money, sneers and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy approaches Chaitanya’s hotel room. The door is slight ajar. He’s about to knock when he hears Chaitanya’s Dad. CHAITANYA’S DAD (0.S.) Just make sure he’s locked in, okay?

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Dad. He’s totally locked in. He's took me around to see the sights last night! Something you’ve never done, by the way. CHAITANYA’S DAD (0.S.) Chaitanya, focus. This man is your enemy. Keep him close but don’t forget that. Remember Donnie Brasco. You want to win? Do you?

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Of course! CHAITANYA’S DAD (0.S.) Then make best friends with him! Get him so that he couldn’t bear to beat you!

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Dad, I got it, okay? No problem. Guy’s face falls. He walks away. Further down the hall we see Guy lean an arm against the wall for support. We see shoulders heave once- and once only. Guy hurls the ice cr down the all, then continues on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy waits in the lobby, with the bagged magazine in hand. Chaitanya approaches.  75.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: What? No! No!

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Plying me with booze? Earning my trust? Huh?

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: Listen, I can explain.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: And what about last night, huh? Thought you’d make me tired? Become best friends along the way so I wouldn’t want to beat you?

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: Listen, I know it’s weird but-

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: You little shitwit just admit I was your damned mark! Chaitanya hems and haws.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: -IT WAS MY DAD’S IDEA, OKAY? He felt you were the biggest threat. The wild card. But I really like you.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Liar.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: It was the truth that I’d never left the hotel before last night. It was truth that you and I became friends!

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: All so that you could win.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: No. Yes. Well, no. The getting you to lose part was my Dad’s idea but you’re cool and I like you. You showed me my first boobs! Guy turns away. Chaitanya scurries around to face him.  76. CHAITANYA (CONT’D) Do you want to see a friend lose? My Dad will be so disappointed in me. Guy takes out the toy cab/police car Chaitanya gave him, drops it on the floor and crushes it with his heel.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Fuck you sideways, Chaiwala! Guy storms out of the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chaitanya chases after Guy.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: Guy! Guy! As Guy walks off a MASKED ASSAILANT with a PIPE rushes Gu WHAP! WHAP! WHAP! Right at the knee! Guy crumples to the ground, screaming. The masked assailant stands over Guy, then freaks and spi and dashes off- DIRECTLY IN FRONT OF AN ONCOMING TAXI CAB. The cab slams on its brakes, sending the Masked Assailant rolling over its hood. A crowd quickly gathers around the commotion. The cabbie gets out of the cab and approaches the Masked Assailant, out cold on the street. The cabbie removes the mask. IT’S DIRECTOR DEAGAN!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Police, paramedics, and looky-loos surround the scene. Director Deagan, now handcuffed on a gurney, is being lif up into an ambulance.  77.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR DEAGAN
dialogues.text: He’s the one you should be arresting! He’s a bad man! A B-A-

dialogues.speaker: D M-A-N
dialogues.text: The ambulance doors close and the ambulance drives off. Jenny sits with Guy, who now has his knee wrapped in ice.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I’m going to go talk to your buddy. Guy’s holding a death stare on Chaitanya, who stands off the distance with his father, talking to the police.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: He’s not my friend and don’t go fucking talking to him! Chaitanya nervously glances over at Guy. The moment is tense.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I need to.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Do it and I’1l go talk to ESPN. I‘1l totally open up.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Try me. Guy limps away. Jenny's phone vibrates. She has an e-mail alert. It reads “Jenny- Guy Trippon info. We're even! Jeremy.” Jenny opens up the e-mail on her phone. Reads. Her eyes g wide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chaitanya studies from his huge binder. His phone rings. picks it up.  78.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DESK
dialogues.text: Yes, your father left a message saying he’1ll be waiting for you in the lobby in five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: (confused) Really? Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chaitanya walks out of his room. Before the door shuts completely, GUY silently limps inside from behind a nearb planter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chaitanya looks around the lobby. No father. Chaitanya freezes- a horrible thought has just crossed hi mind. Chaitanya runs for the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chaitanya runs as fast as he can to his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chaitanya scrambles inside...HIS BINDER IS GONE! Chaitanya notices a flickering reflection from his window Chaitanya looks out his window to see Guy below in the parking lot, standing next to the BURNING BINDER! Guy loo up and flips Chaitanya the double bird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a knock at Guy’s door. Guy limps over to and ope it to face a PIZZA DELIVERY GUY holding TWENTY PIZZA BOXE  79.

dialogues.speaker: PIZZA DELIVERY GUY
dialogues.text: That will be two hundred and eighty dollars, not including tip. Guy grits his teeth and slams his door.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Amateur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There’s a knock on Chaitanya’s door. He opens it and is greeted by MARZIPAN.

dialogues.speaker: MARZIPAN
dialogues.text: Hey, Sugar! Suddenly ANOTHER HOOKER APPROACHES.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: What are you doin’ here, bitch?!

dialogues.speaker: MARZIPAN
dialogues.text: This is my hood, bitch!

dialogues.speaker: WHO YOU CALLING BITCH, BITCH
dialogues.text: Chaitanya slams his door shut, completely freaked out as two prostitutes wage war out in the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy jumps awake to his door being rapped hard.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: D.C.P.D. Open up, Sir.  80.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Yeah, right! Nice try Chaiwala! Who’d you hire, the doorman?

dialogues.speaker: POLICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sir, we've received a call that you’re holding someone against their will in your room, open the door or we will open it for you. Guy sits up in bed. Decides to play along.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: That's right, coppers! I've got a hostage! And I'll do her if you get any closer! Then, I'1l fuckin’ do myself, you hear?! Guy listens, footsteps hurry away from his door.

dialogues.speaker: GUY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Complete fucking amateur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy lies asleep on his bed.

dialogues.speaker: BOOM
dialogues.text: The door splinters open!

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Huh...whah? A horde of SWAT stumble into the room and on top of Guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny walks out with Guy.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: That little fucking bastard!

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Hey, at least they didn’t press charges.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: He knew I wouldn't believe it was the real cops. It’s war!  81.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Guy. I gotta talk to you about something. I’ve been digging around and...I found out who your father is. Maybe...just stop walking for a second. Jenny stops Guy. Looks into his eyes. Takes a deep breath

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As incredible as this sounds, Guy, your father is Scribbs President Bill Bowman.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Yeah. I know.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Wait, what? You do?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: My mother told me when she was dying. He was a traveling encyclopedia salesman, she was a waitress at a diner he passed through all the time. When she got pregnant he stuck around for awhile or something, but once I was born, he headed for the hills and never looked back.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: So Bowman doesn’t have any idea who you are-

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: -Not a fucking clue. And he’s not going to until I finish making a mockery out of what he seems to love more than anything else, the spelling bee.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Guy! This is huge.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: It's not important to your story, if that’s what you’re trying to drive at.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Like hell it isn’t! This is completely important. Everything else falls to the wayside for this. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is now the whole point of my article.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: No fucking way.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Look, not wanting me to get a quote from some kid is one thing, but you can’t really tell me what to write.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: I’m doing it right now.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I like you and I thought you liked me, but nothing gets in the way of me doing my job well.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Are you kidding me? Nothing gets in the way of your shitty little tabloid piece? Spare me. Why don’t you knock off this professional reporter act. You write for a scabby rag that fat housewives wash down with a pint of ice cream every week. Jenny’s clearly stung by Guy’s words.

dialogues.speaker: GUY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you write one word about this, I‘1l never talk to you again!

dialogues.speaker: FINE
dialogues.text: IT HAS TO BE! You just do what you have to do and I’1l do what I have to do.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Whatever. You fucking ingrate! Jenny scoffs. She’s so enraged she’s speechless. Jenny storms off. Guy watches her go, angry, yet torn by tinge of regret.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: And welcome everyone to the big tamale, the final countdown, where the eye meets the tiger! Pete, if you thought the going got weird during the Bee yesterday, just listen to what happened when the semi-final round was over. Reports have come in that National Spelling Bee Director Bernice Deagan has been arrested and charged with assault with a deadly weapon, on none other than Guy Duncan!

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: She tried to Tanya Harding him, Chuck. With a pipe. Anda ski mask. Allegedly. Much to America’s disappointment, Guy only suffered minor injuries and will be competing in the final round.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Un. Believable. This morning Scribbs COO Bill Bowman announced that Director Deagan has been removed from her position and that he himself will oversee the final round today. And we are fortunate enough to have Mr. Bowman with us, in Washington D.C., right now. Bowman steps into frame.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: Thank you, Chuck. I would like to take the opportunity to address this unique situation to everyone watching out there. I regret the alleged actions of former Director Bernice Deagan. As you know, I myself am a former bee champ. Before I became one of the most influential and powerful executives in America, I learned first hand that the bee is about sportsmanship, not assault and battery. I look forward to moving past this ugly incident and am very excited to personally crown our next National Spelling Bee Champ, whoever that may be. 83.  84.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: From your lips to God’s ears. Pete, take it away.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: So let’s get to it! The final round of this year’s Scribbs Institute National Spelling Bee, where the last speller standing walks away with five hundred thousand dollars- Bowman leans in to interject.

dialogues.speaker: BOWMAN
dialogues.text: -And a lifetime supply of dictionaries and encyclopedias-

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: -blah blah blah FIVE HUNDRED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All twenty five competitors sit up on the stage as the ju and audience and Bowman sit before them. Disheveled and worse for the wear, Guy limps past Chaitan who’s wearing a blazer that has one sleeve obviously long than the other.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: What happened to the duds? Looks like a “friend” got hold of them. Chaitanya’s tired and grumpy.

dialogues.speaker: CHAITANYA
dialogues.text: You got arrested.

dialogues.speaker: GUY

I’m your son and I just want to say, FUCK YOU and this is a reporter friend of mine who is going to write an entire article about it whether you like it or not! Mr. Bowman’s face goes slack. Jenny is incredibly touched Guy's gesture. Guy tensely waits to see what Bowman says next, preparing for the worst.

dialogues.text: Chaitanya punches it as the three kids ride their bikes a fast as their feet can peddle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A high speed chase! As the police car tears after the three screaming kids on their bikes...through the streets, over lawns, through parking lots. And all the while we hear Chaitanya and Guy laughing together. Like friends do.
